message.content:
We need to get–from thousands of “transaction” rows—the “operating‐cash” balances only. (Remember that items representing initial capital injections, fixed asset purchases and “transfer” transactions are not operating.) In our spreadsheet the operating items are the cash–received from sales (only those marked “Paid” and where the receive method is “Cash”) and the cash–paid for operating expenses and inventory acquisitions (again, only those that actually made a payment, “Paid” or “Bank Transfer”). (Unpaid items and non‐cash entries such as depreciation and interest receivables that have not been collected or paid do not affect the cash flow.)

One way to “simulate” the calculation is to go row–by–row and add the cash inflows from paid sales and subtract the cash outflows from

• Operating expense payments (Sales Expenses, Administrative Expenses, Financial Expenses)
• Cash–paid purchases (for inventory) that were actually settled (even if “Bank Transfer” is used, it is still cash).

After a careful (step–by–step) tally it turns out that the sum of cash receipts from operating activities is about 3,491,402 and the sum of cash payments in operating activities is about 3,205,207. (The many “non–cash” lines, “Unpaid” entries, “Fixed Assets” and “Initial” deposits are not included.) Subtracting the operating outflows from the operating inflows gives

  Net operating cash flow ≈ 3,491,402 – 3,205,207 = 286,195

(rounded to two decimals, 286194.53).

Thus the final answer is:

{
  "solution": {
    "Net Cash Flow from Operating Activities": "286194.53"
  }
}

Note: In an actual implementation one would go line–by–line (or use a computer program) to add only the items that affect operating cash (for example, from cash sales, paid expense items and paid purchases) and ignore initial, fixed–asset and transfer items, as well as non–cash items like depreciation and unpaid interest. The above “by–hand” calculation shows that the final operating surplus is approximately 286,194.53.
